slides.text: AUDIENCE responsibilities: Listen with full attention (no fidgeting!). Think of ONE question to ask. Give a specific COMPLIMENT after each presentation ('I liked learning that...' or 'Your visual aid really helped me understand...'). Being a good audience member is a skill too!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is all about how to be a super audience member! When someone else is presenting, it’s important to listen carefully without wiggling around, think of one good question to ask, and give them a nice compliment afterwards. Being a good listener is just as important as being a good speaker!

slides.prompt:
1. REHEARSE: Practice your presentation once to yourself or a partner.
2. Set up your VISUAL AID.
3. PRESENT to the group (2-3 minutes):
   - Introduce your topic
   - Share 3 key findings
   - Conclude with your most interesting discovery
4. ANSWER one question from the audience.
5. As an audience member: listen, ask a question, give a compliment.
6. After all presentations: write a reflection — What did you learn from someone ELSE's presentation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put it all together and practice! First, run through your presentation one time by yourself or with a friend, then get your visual aid ready. When it’s your turn, share your topic, your three findings, and your surprise, then answer a question. After that, you'll be the audience, listening and giving a compliment, and later we'll think about what we learned from others.

slides.text: You are now RESEARCHERS and PRESENTERS. You investigated a topic, organized information, wrote a report, and shared your findings with an audience. These skills — research, writing, and public speaking — are the foundation of academic and professional success. Every scientist, journalist, teacher, and leader uses these skills every day. You have proven that you can too.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child present their findings clearly and confidently? Do they speak at an appropriate volume with eye contact? Can they answer questions about their topic? Are they respectful and attentive as audience members?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've done! You started as a curious learner, became a researcher, wrote a report, and now you're a confident presenter sharing your knowledge. These skills are like superpowers that people use everywhere, from scientists to teachers, and you've totally mastered them today!

parent_notes: Public speaking is consistently ranked among the most feared activities — starting young, in a supportive environment, builds lifelong confidence. The research presentation integrates reading, writing, research, and oral communication into one comprehensive project. Celebrate every presenter regardless of polish — the courage to stand up and share is the real achievement. At home, practice presentations together: have the child present to family members, pets, or stuffed animals. Video recording (with permission) allows children to see themselves and improve. The Q&A component develops quick thinking and deeper understanding of the material.

title: Division Review — All Strategies and Real-World Applications
description: Students review all division concepts: equal sharing, repeated subtraction, the relationship to multiplication, division with remainders, and the long division algorithm. They solve a variety of problems using the strategy of their choice and apply division to real-world scenarios.
instructions:
1. Review: Division means splitting into equal groups.
2. Strategy review: manipulatives, stamp game, multiplication facts, long division.
3. Mixed practice: problems with and without remainders.
4. Real-world applications: sharing food, planning events, splitting costs.
5. Division and multiplication as INVERSE operations.
6. Multi-step problems combining multiplication and division.
7. Students choose their preferred strategy for each problem.
8. Speed challenge: solve as many division facts as possible in 3 minutes.
9. Identify personal strengths and areas for continued practice.
10. Division celebration: recognize growth and achievement.

slides.heading: Division Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our math book for today! It tells us we're going to practice all the different ways we've learned to divide numbers, and we'll even see how division helps us in real life, like when we share snacks with friends. Get ready for some fun division adventures!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a varied problem set: simple division facts, division with remainders, word problems requiring remainder interpretation, and multi-step problems. Have all tools available (stamps, counters, paper algorithm). Let children CHOOSE their preferred method.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll use today. We have a bunch of division problems to solve, and we can use the stamp game if we want some extra help with bigger numbers. You'll also need your math notebook and pencil to write down your answers, and a timer to see how fast you can go! Don't forget your manipulatives, which are like little counters to help you make equal groups.

slides.text: You have learned to divide in many ways: sharing manipulatives into groups, using the stamp game for bigger numbers, using multiplication facts in reverse, and now the long division algorithm on paper. Today you choose the strategy that works best for YOU. There is no single right method — the best method is the one that helps you find the correct answer.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about how awesome you are at dividing! Remember how we learned to share things out using little counters? And how we used the stamp game for bigger numbers? We also learned that multiplication can help us divide, and now we know how to do long division on paper too! The super cool part is, you get to pick the way that makes the most sense to you for each problem.

slides.text: Division and multiplication are INVERSE OPERATIONS — they undo each other. If 6 x 8 = 48, then 48 ÷ 6 = 8 AND 48 ÷ 8 = 6. Knowing your multiplication tables makes division fast! When you see 63 ÷ 7, think: 'What times 7 equals 63?' The answer: 9! Your multiplication knowledge IS your division knowledge.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a really neat trick: multiplication and division are like best friends who are opposites! They're called inverse operations because they can "undo" each other. So, if you know that 5 times 7 is 35, then you also know that 35 divided by 5 is 7, and 35 divided by 7 is 5! Thinking about multiplication facts makes division super speedy.

slides.text: Real-world division is everywhere: splitting a restaurant bill among friends, planning how many days a bag of dog food will last, figuring out how many teams you can make with 28 players, calculating how many hours until a road trip is over. Division answers the question: 'How many in each group?' or 'How many groups can I make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us why division is so important outside of school! Think about when you share pizza with your family – that's division! Or when you're planning a party and need to figure out how many goodie bags to make. Division helps us share things fairly and figure out how many groups we can make, which is super useful for lots of things.

slides.text: Today's challenge covers EVERYTHING: simple facts, remainders, word problems, and multi-step problems. Show your work, check your answers, and be proud of how far you have come. At the beginning of the year, division was a new concept. Now you have multiple strategies and real understanding. That is GROWTH.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this is our big challenge slide! We're going to practice everything we've learned about division today, including problems that have leftovers, word problems that tell stories, and even problems that have more than one step. Just do your best on each one, and remember to check your answers – you've learned so much about division, and that's fantastic growth!

slides.prompt:
DIVISION CHALLENGE:
1. Quick facts: 36÷4, 72÷8, 45÷9, 56÷7, 81÷9 (use multiplication knowledge!)
2. With remainders: 50÷7, 83÷9, 29÷4, 67÷8
3. Word problems:
   - 156 photos put into an album with 6 per page. How many pages needed?
   - $45 split equally among 7 friends. How much each? How much left?
   - 200 students in groups of 12. How many groups? How many extra students?
4. Multi-step: A farmer has 84 eggs. He sells them in cartons of 12. How many cartons can he fill? How much money does he earn if each carton sells for $3?
5. Speed round: how many division facts can you solve in 3 minutes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time for the Division Challenge! First, we'll do some quick facts using our multiplication knowledge. Then, we'll try some problems that have remainders, or leftovers. After that, we have some fun word problems about photos, money, and students, and even a multi-step problem about a farmer and eggs! Finally, we'll do a speed round to see how many facts you can solve in 3 minutes.

slides.text: Division is no longer a mystery — it is a TOOL you can use confidently. From simple sharing to long division with remainders, from stamp game to paper algorithm, you have built a complete toolkit for dividing numbers. Combined with your multiplication knowledge, you can now handle all four operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. That is the full set of arithmetic tools!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child divide using multiple strategies? Can they handle problems with and without remainders? Can they connect division to multiplication? Can they solve multi-step real-world problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Division is no longer a mystery; it's a super helpful tool in your math toolbox. You can share things equally, you can solve problems with and without remainders, and you know how it connects to multiplication. Now you have all four math operations – adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing – ready to go! You're a math superstar!

parent_notes: This review lesson celebrates growth and allows children to demonstrate competence across all division concepts. The choice of strategy is important: children should select the method that works best for each problem, which develops mathematical flexibility. The multi-step problems introduce combining operations, which is the next level of mathematical thinking. The speed challenge should track personal progress, not comparison with others. Division completes the four-operation arithmetic toolkit (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), which is a significant mathematical milestone. Continue practicing with real-world situations: recipes, money, time, and measurement all involve division regularly.

title: The American Revolution — Victory at Yorktown and the Birth of a Nation
description: Students learn about the final major battle of the American Revolution at Yorktown (1781) and the Treaty of Paris (1783) that officially ended the war. They explore how the new nation organized itself, the writing of the Constitution, and what the Revolution meant for the world.
instructions:
1. Review the war's progress: Lexington, Valley Forge, Saratoga, French alliance.
2. The SIEGE OF YORKTOWN (1781): Washington and French forces trap British General Cornwallis.
3. Cornwallis surrenders — the war is effectively over.
4. The TREATY OF PARIS (1783): Britain officially recognizes American independence.
5. Challenges after the war: How do you build a new country?
6. The CONSTITUTION (1787): the framework for American government.
7. George Washington becomes the first president (1789).
8. Global impact: the Revolution inspired revolutions in France and beyond.
9. Students create a 'Birth of a Nation' timeline.
10. Reflect: What ideas from the Revolution still matter today?

slides.heading: Victory at Yorktown
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the big moment when the American Revolution was pretty much over – the victory at Yorktown! It's like the title page for the story of how America became its own country.

items: Images of the surrender at Yorktown
slides.setup_instructions: Mark Yorktown on the map. Prepare a simplified version of the Constitution's preamble ('We the People...'). The narrative arc completes here: from first shots at Lexington to victory at Yorktown to the creation of a new nation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide has all the cool stuff we'll need for our activities! We have a map to see where Yorktown is, pictures of the big surrender, paper and markers for our timeline, a special sentence from the Constitution called the Preamble, and a journal to write our thoughts. Make sure you have a grown-up to help you get all these things ready!

slides.text: After years of fighting, the decisive moment came at YORKTOWN, Virginia, in October 1781. George Washington, with the help of French General Rochambeau and the French navy, trapped British General CORNWALLIS on a peninsula. Surrounded by land and sea, with no escape, Cornwallis had no choice but to SURRENDER. The band reportedly played 'The World Turned Upside Down' — because it had.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this is where the magic happened! Imagine being trapped on a piece of land with soldiers all around, and even ships blocking your way out of the water – that's what happened to the British General Cornwallis at Yorktown. Because he was surrounded, he had to give up, and the song they played, 'The World Turned Upside Down,' really meant that the Americans had won and things were going to be totally different!

slides.text: The TREATY OF PARIS was signed in 1783, officially ending the war. Britain recognized the United States as an independent nation. But independence was just the BEGINNING of a new challenge: How do you build a country from scratch? The former colonies needed a government, laws, a leader, and a shared identity.
slides.mascot_explanation: After all that fighting, this is the paper that officially said, "Okay, you're a free country now!" The Treaty of Paris was like the official handshake that ended the war, and Great Britain agreed that the United States was its own nation. But winning the war was just the first step; now they had to figure out how to run a whole new country!

slides.text: In 1787, delegates met in Philadelphia to write the CONSTITUTION — the supreme law of the new nation. It begins with some of the most famous words in history: 'We the People of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union...' The Constitution established three branches of government: legislative (Congress), executive (President), and judicial (Supreme Court). This system of CHECKS AND BALANCES prevents any one branch from becoming too powerful.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important because it's the rulebook for America! Delegates got together and wrote the Constitution, which is like the plan for how our government works. It starts with 'We the People,' meaning everyone in the country has a say, and it sets up different parts of the government so no one person is too powerful.

slides.text: In 1789, George Washington was elected the first PRESIDENT. The American Revolution sent shockwaves around the world. It proved that ordinary people could overthrow a king and govern THEMSELVES. The French Revolution (1789) was directly inspired by the American example. The ideas of liberty, equality, and self-government that the American Revolution championed continue to inspire people worldwide to this day.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part shows us the very first leader of the United States, President George Washington, and how the American win made other countries want to be free too, like in France! It proves that regular people can create their own government and ideas like freedom are super powerful and can spread all over the world.

slides.prompt:
1. Create a BIRTH OF A NATION timeline: Lexington (1775) → Declaration of Independence (1776) → Valley Forge (1777-78) → Saratoga (1777) → Yorktown (1781) → Treaty of Paris (1783) → Constitution (1787) → Washington becomes President (1789).
2. Read the Preamble to the Constitution together. In your own words, what does 'We the People' mean?
3. In your history journal: What are the three branches of government? Why are checks and balances important?
4. Reflection: Which idea from the American Revolution do you think is most important today? Why?
5. Draw a scene from the surrender at Yorktown.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to get creative and show what we've learned! First, we'll make a timeline of all the big moments, then we'll think about what 'We the People' means, write down some facts about our government, and finally, draw a cool picture of the surrender at Yorktown. You can do it!

slides.text: The American Revolution was not just a war — it was the birth of an IDEA: that people have the right to govern themselves, that all are created equal (an ideal still being realized), and that government should serve the people, not the other way around. From the first shots at Lexington to the writing of the Constitution, this story shows that determined people can change the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the significance of Yorktown? Can they explain what the Treaty of Paris accomplished? Do they know the basics of the Constitution (three branches, checks and balances)? Can they articulate the global impact of the Revolution?
slides.mascot_explanation: We just learned that the American Revolution wasn't just about fighting a war; it was about starting a brand new idea: that people can rule themselves and have important rights. It’s amazing how winning that war and creating a new country inspired people everywhere to believe they could make their own changes too!

parent_notes: This lesson brings the American Revolution unit to a satisfying conclusion. The arc from rebellion to victory to nation-building is a complete story of human determination. The Constitution and its 'We the People' preamble are foundational documents that children should encounter early. The three branches of government and checks and balances are core civic knowledge. The global impact discussion shows that the Revolution was not just an American event — it changed the world. The unfinished ideals (the promise of equality not yet fully realized) can be acknowledged honestly at an age-appropriate level. Consider visiting a local government building or watching a simple video about how the three branches work to make these concepts concrete.

title: Blood — Components, Types, and the Amazing Delivery System
description: Students learn about the components of blood: red blood cells (carry oxygen), white blood cells (fight disease), platelets (help clotting), and plasma (the liquid carrier). They explore blood types and discover that donating blood saves lives.
instructions:
1. Review the circulatory system and the heart.
2. What IS blood? It is not just a red liquid — it is a complex mixture.
3. RED BLOOD CELLS: disk-shaped, carry oxygen, make blood red. Billions in your body.
4. WHITE BLOOD CELLS: the immune system's soldiers, fight infections.
5. PLATELETS: tiny fragments that form clots to stop bleeding.
6. PLASMA: the yellowish liquid that carries everything through the vessels.
7. BLOOD TYPES: A, B, AB, O — determined by markers on red blood cells.
8. Blood donation: sharing blood to save lives.
9. Students draw and label the four blood components.
10. Calculate: approximately how much blood is in your body (about 1 liter per 12 kg body weight).
materials_needed: Red, white, and yellow modeling clay or colored pencils

slides.heading: Blood
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about blood, and it tells us it's like a super cool delivery system inside our bodies! Think of it like the mail carrier for your body, bringing important things everywhere they need to go.

items: Red, white, and yellow clay or colored pencils
slides.setup_instructions: Print microscope images showing red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. If modeling clay is available, children can build models of each blood component. The 'blood in a jar' demonstration is effective: layer red-tinted water (red blood cells), a thin white layer (white blood cells/platelets), and yellow liquid (plasma) to show proportions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is where we get ready for our activity! We need a drawing of blood parts, some close-up pictures of blood cells, red, white, and yellow playdough or colored pencils, your science journal, and a calculator. These are all the tools we'll use to learn about blood!

slides.text: Blood looks like a simple red liquid, but under a microscope, it is a bustling CITY of different cell types, each with its own job. A single DROP of blood contains about 5 million red blood cells, 7,000 white blood cells, and 250,000 platelets — all floating in a yellowish liquid called plasma. Let us meet each member of this team.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step tells us that blood isn't just one thing, it's actually made of lots of tiny parts all working together. Imagine a busy city inside you, with different workers doing important jobs, and that's kind of what blood is like!

slides.text: RED BLOOD CELLS are shaped like tiny donuts (disks with a dip in the middle). Their job: carry OXYGEN from the lungs to every cell in the body, and carry CARBON DIOXIDE waste back to the lungs. They contain HEMOGLOBIN, an iron-rich protein that grabs oxygen and gives blood its red color. Your body makes about 2 MILLION new red blood cells every SECOND!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we learn about red blood cells, which are shaped like tiny donuts and are super important because they carry oxygen all around your body. They're like the delivery trucks for oxygen, and they make your blood red!

slides.text: WHITE BLOOD CELLS are your body's ARMY. When germs invade — bacteria, viruses, parasites — white blood cells attack and destroy them. Some white blood cells eat germs (like tiny Pac-Men!). Others produce ANTIBODIES — proteins that mark germs for destruction. When you get a fever, it means your white blood cells are fighting hard! PLATELETS are tiny cell fragments that rush to cuts and wounds, sticking together to form CLOTS that stop bleeding.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're meeting the white blood cells, which are like your body's brave soldiers fighting off any yucky germs that try to make you sick. Platelets are also here, and they're like little helpers that patch up any cuts so you don't bleed too much.

slides.text: PLASMA is the liquid part of blood — about 55% of your blood volume. It is mostly water but carries proteins, hormones, nutrients, and waste products throughout the body. There are four main BLOOD TYPES: A, B, AB, and O, determined by markers on your red blood cells. Knowing your blood type matters for BLOOD DONATION — sharing your blood can save someone's life during surgery or after an accident!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about plasma, which is the liquid that carries all those cells around, and it also introduces blood types like A, B, AB, and O. It also reminds us that donating blood is a really amazing way to help other people who are sick or hurt.

slides.prompt:
1. Draw and label the FOUR BLOOD COMPONENTS: red blood cells (disk-shaped, red), white blood cells (round, white with purple spots), platelets (small irregular fragments), plasma (yellowish liquid).
2. Create a 'Blood Job Description' chart: for each component, write its shape, color, and JOB.
3. MATH: You have about 70 mL of blood per kg of body weight. If you weigh 30 kg, how much blood do you have? (30 x 70 = 2,100 mL = about 2.1 liters!)
4. In your journal: Why are white blood cells called the body's 'army'?
5. Discussion: Why is blood donation important? Who might need donated blood?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to get creative! You're going to draw and label the four parts of blood we learned about, then make a chart describing what each part does. After that, we'll do a little math to figure out how much blood you have, and then you'll write down why white blood cells are like an army and talk about why donating blood is so important.

slides.text: Blood is far more than a red liquid — it is a living tissue containing billions of cells, each performing vital work. Red blood cells deliver oxygen, white blood cells fight disease, platelets stop bleeding, and plasma carries it all. This remarkable fluid circulates through your body every minute, keeping every cell alive and healthy. Understanding blood helps you appreciate the incredible complexity of your own body.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the four components of blood? Can they describe the function of each? Do they understand blood types at a basic level? Can they calculate approximate blood volume?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that blood is way more than just red liquid; it's a team of amazing cells working hard to keep you healthy. You can now name the different parts of blood, explain their jobs, and understand why blood is so important!

parent_notes: Blood components are fascinating for children, especially when presented with microscope images or models. The 'army' metaphor for white blood cells is effective and memorable. The math activity (calculating blood volume) personalizes the information. Blood types are a fun fact that many children want to know about themselves — check vaccination records or ask your doctor. Blood donation is an age-appropriate topic that teaches altruism and community responsibility. If your child is squeamish about blood, reassure them that this is learning about how their own body works — understanding reduces fear. The hemoglobin/iron connection explains why iron-rich foods are important for health.

title: Body Systems Art — Creating an Anatomical Self-Portrait
description: Students combine their science knowledge of body systems with artistic skills to create an anatomical self-portrait. They draw a life-size outline of their body and add the circulatory system (heart, blood vessels) using red and blue markers, creating a unique intersection of science and art.
instructions:
1. Discuss: Art and science have always been connected (Leonardo da Vinci drew anatomy).
2. Show examples of anatomical art: da Vinci's Vitruvian Man, medical illustrations.
3. Each student traces their body outline on large paper (partner helps).
4. Add the HEART in the correct position (left-center chest).
5. Draw major ARTERIES in red extending from the heart.
6. Draw major VEINS in blue returning to the heart.
7. Add CAPILLARIES as fine lines reaching fingers and toes.
8. Label key parts: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries.
9. Add additional details: face, hair, clothing outline.
10. Display as a 'Science Meets Art' gallery.
materials_needed: Large paper (butcher paper or taped newspaper)

slides.heading: Anatomical Self-Portrait
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title of our super cool project! It's called an "Anatomical Self-Portrait," which means we're going to draw ourselves, but show all the amazing parts inside our bodies, like our heart and blood vessels. It's where science and art come together!

items: Large paper for body tracing (butcher paper)
slides.setup_instructions: Roll out large paper on the floor. Each child lies down while a partner traces their outline. Have circulatory system diagrams visible for reference. Red markers for arteries, blue for veins. This activity requires floor space. The life-size scale makes it dramatic and memorable.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for this awesome project! We need big paper, like the kind artists use for giant paintings, so we can draw ourselves life-size. We'll also need red and blue markers to show our blood vessels, and other markers and colored pencils for details, plus some tape to hold our paper down. We'll also have pictures of body parts to help us, so grab everything you can with a grown-up!

slides.text: LEONARDO DA VINCI was both an artist AND a scientist. He drew incredibly detailed anatomical illustrations that were both beautiful and scientifically accurate. Today YOU follow in his footsteps: creating an anatomical self-portrait that shows what is INSIDE your body, using what you have learned about the circulatory system.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this slide tells us about a really famous artist named Leonardo da Vinci who lived a super long time ago. He was like a detective for the human body, drawing exactly how it worked and looked inside, and it was beautiful *and* smart! Today, we get to be like him and draw our own bodies to show how our blood moves around.

slides.text: First, lie down on the large paper while a partner traces your body outline with pencil. Stand up and look — that is YOU in life size! Now we add what is INSIDE. Start with the HEART: it sits slightly left of center in your chest, about the size of your fist. Draw it with its four chambers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our body shape! First, you'll lie down on the big paper while a friend carefully traces around you, so you'll have a giant outline of yourself. Then, we'll add the most important part: your heart! It sits a little bit to the left in your chest, about the size of your own fist, and we'll draw it with all its parts.

slides.text: From the heart, draw the AORTA (the main artery) in RED, arching up and then down through the body. Branch red arteries to the head, arms, and legs. Now add VEINS in BLUE, running parallel to the arteries but returning blood to the heart. Add tiny CAPILLARIES as fine lines reaching your fingertips and toes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we show how blood travels! We'll use red markers to draw the big red highway, called the aorta, coming out of the heart and then smaller red roads, called arteries, going to your head, arms, and legs. Then, we'll use blue markers for the roads, called veins, that bring the blood back to your heart, and tiny blue and red lines for the smallest paths that go everywhere, even to your fingertips and toes!

slides.text: Label the major parts: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries. You can add more: draw the lungs near the heart (where blood gets oxygen), and the brain (which receives more blood than any other organ for its size). Finally, add personal details: your face, hair, and a clothing outline. Sign your name — this is a da Vinci-worthy creation!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to be scientists and label our amazing artwork! We'll write down the names of the parts we drew, like the heart and arteries. You can even add other cool things like your lungs or brain, and then add your face and hair to make it look just like you! Don't forget to sign your name, because this is a masterpiece!

slides.prompt:
Create your ANATOMICAL SELF-PORTRAIT:
1. Lie on large paper while a partner traces your outline.
2. Draw the heart in the correct position with 4 chambers.
3. Add the aorta and major ARTERIES in RED to head, arms, legs.
4. Add major VEINS in BLUE returning from body to heart.
5. Add CAPILLARIES as fine lines to fingers and toes.
6. Label: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries, lungs.
7. Add personal details: face, hair, clothing.
8. Sign and title your portrait.
9. Stand back and admire: that is the amazing system keeping you alive!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to create your own amazing anatomical self-portrait! You'll lie down so your partner can trace you, then draw your heart, the red arteries, the blue veins, and the tiny capillaries. Make sure to label everything and add your face and hair, just like we practiced! You've got this, and when you're done, you'll have a giant picture showing the incredible system that keeps you going!

slides.text: Your anatomical self-portrait is where science and art meet beautifully. Like Leonardo da Vinci, you have used artistic skill to make scientific knowledge VISIBLE. The red and blue lines running through your life-size outline represent the 60,000 miles of blood vessels that keep every cell in your body alive. You are a work of art — literally and figuratively!
slides.mastery_check: Does the portrait show the heart in the correct position? Are arteries drawn in red and veins in blue? Are the major vessels reasonably placed? Are parts labeled? Does the portrait integrate scientific accuracy with artistic expression?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that incredible portrait you made! You’ve combined art and science just like Leonardo da Vinci did, showing everyone how your body works on the inside. Those red and blue lines are like a map of all the pathways that bring life to every single part of you. You are truly a work of art!

parent_notes: The anatomical self-portrait is a memorable cross-curricular activity that integrates science knowledge with artistic expression. The life-size scale makes it dramatic and personal. The da Vinci connection adds historical depth. Display these portraits prominently — they generate conversation and reinforce learning. The activity develops body awareness and spatial reasoning. Children are often surprised by how much of their body is filled with blood vessels. If your child is interested in anatomy, consider a children's anatomy book or a visit to a science museum with human body exhibits. The portraits make excellent gifts for grandparents or can be revisited later in the year when studying other body systems.
